bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Macia, November 13, 1944

div1.p: Hench is worried about the condition of Building No. 1. He does not want it to suffer the fate of its companion building which crashed in a hurricane. Hench is thinking about erecting an outer protective shell, and is wondering how much it would cost.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Macia, November 13, 1944
div1.opener:
PSH/cb
copies sent to Rojas
Ramos
Moran
also sent Horigantes Medicos
13 November, 1944
Manzana de Gomez 325
My dear Mr. Macia:
div1.p:
Some weeks ago, before the recent hurricane, I got worried about
the little building at Camp Lazear. I am so fearful, lest it be damaged
further by the weather. I wrote to Mr. Moran, asking if he, as my agent,
would contact you, to see if something might be done about erecting a
protective frame to enclose completely the little building. I hate to
discommode anyone who might be living in the little shack, but the little
building is of such historical significance that I felt emboldened to
suggest that it be cared for properly, and I wish to help in the expense
of its protection.

Mr. Moran does not have an automobile, and I fear that I have im-
posed already greatly on his time. When I heard of the recent hurricane,
I did really become alarmed. Mr. Moran has not had the occasion to write
to me but I sincerely hope that the little building is still intact and
has not suffered the fate of its companion building, which crashed in
the hurricane of 1926.

Two weeks ago, in New York, I had the privilege of meeting Doctor
Ramos, and we discussed the proper protection of the little building.
I would appreciate it greatly if you would let me know whether it would
be feasible to erect a strong outer shell, completely enveloping the
little building. My original thought, before I heard of the hurricane,
was that this shell would be of strong planking and tar paper, but in
view of the hurricane, I wonder whether it would not be much better to
erect some sort of a semi-permanent shell, made either of brick (perhaps
old secondhand brick, cheaply bought) or other suitable semi-permanent
material which might probably withstand a hurricane. I have no idea
how much the erection of such an outer protective shell would cost in
Cuba. I do have a small personal fund available and would be very grate-
ful indeed if, from your busy hours, you could give me a little time to
discuss this matter. My Army address is as given at the head of the letter.

closer.signed:
PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M. C.
Chief of the Medical Service
